Leave the globe alone.
This apparition does not appear to be able to interact with you.
Aga soo... yeda aga soo! Ur hoa ben, ur lata... nu...NUUUU!
You will never sully Layenne's Tomb, mortal sludge!
Me already got snow globe. You need give me other reward.
I already got the snow globe. You better come up with another reward.
Me gonna just kill you now!
I think I'll just kill you instead.
Okay. You go now. Me not need reward.
Fine. I guess I don't need a reward. Get out of here.
Well, this is most awkward isn't it? You have no need of my information and I have nothing else to offer. Perhaps we should just consider this a good deed and part ways.
You will never take the snow globe, insignificant mortal!
A bear growls.
A puma snarls.
A dog barks.
A dragon roars.
This looks like some sort of wizard's summoning chambers. It looks like it could actually be used.
You have returned, mortal. Have you reconsidered my offer? Do wish me to... help you?
With these talismans back in my possession my lost power will be restored and I can escape this prison. For each piece of my jewelry you bring me, mortal, I will... help you.
This room looks like a functional wizard's lab.
<StartAction>Your attacks have no effect. You will have to destroy the protection glyphs to make the golem vulnerable.</Start>
Intruders must be destroyed. Activating protection glyphs!
There is a sign on the door saying that the chamber is the private quarters of Chief Obould Many Arrows. He is obviously not here but you suspect he may return.
No puny <race> will enter here!
Die, puny intruder!
Hiss!
You die!
You have defiled Layenne's tomb, fleshling!

Neverwinter's Spymaster is holding up remarkably well considering the grave consequences of Aribeth's unexpected betrayal. However, beneath the confident assurance he projects there seems to be a subtle discomfort at having been thrust from the shadows into the prominent and highly visible position of Lord Nasher's right hand.
The ornaments on this man's garb distinguish him as the leader of the Uthgardt Black Lion tribe.
This woman is a common farm wife.
This man is one of the local settlers conscripted to defend Fort Ilkard.
There is a pompous arrogance in the manner of Fort Ilkard's commander.
Though dressed as a simple farm wife, this gnome has an air that suggests she is not to be trifled with.
This gnome is one of the local settlers conscripted to defend Fort Ilkard.
This burly gnome bears the look of a gruff, well-seasoned warrior.
This orcish bandit is as large and fierce looking as his reputation would suggest.
Though resembling the reptilian humanoids known as lizardmen there is an intelligence in the eyes of this creature not usually seen in the species.
This young woman seems quite intent on enjoying the libations served in this establishment.
From the iron collar around his neck it is obvious this man is a slave.
Though his features bear a kindly smile there is an ominous air about this cleric, for he holds power over life and death.
There is something imperious and cruel in the bearing of this reptilian humanoid.
In addition to being one of the largest orcs you have ever seen, there is a gleam of dangerous cunning in Obould's eyes.
This man is a member of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
The markings on this woman's clothes identify her as an Uthgardt barbarian of the Golden Eagle tribe.
The markings on this man's clothes identify him as an Uthgardt barbarian of the Golden Eagle tribe.
This half-orc, though as ugly as most of his kind, actually possess a glimmer of intelligence in his features.
This Frost Giant is the son of Gerti Orelsdottr.
This elf is obviously a prisoner of the fire giants.
King Skrogg
The Fire Giant king looks neither royal nor wise, but rather resembles a cruel and stupid bully.
Covered in wicked-looking scars, the ancient colossal Red Dragon nicknamed "Old Snarl" is perhaps the most fearsome and powerful single mortal creature in all of Faerun.
The aura of true majesty one would expect in an adult black dragon is undercut by the vapid, mindless expression on this beast's face.
Even for his kind, this dwarven smith is stocky and heavily muscled - the result of many years spent hammering away at his forge.
The eyes of this middle-aged shopkeeper are those of a wily and successful businessman.
This man is one of the many commoners who has come to Beorunna's Well to help see to the various needs of the soldiers in camp.
Dylan
Alekos
This dwarf is one of the many commoners who has come to Beorunna's Well to join the Lords' Alliance Cause.
This man is obviously one of the many soldiers who have been recruited to the Lords' Alliance cause.
This woman is one of the many commoners who has come to Beorunna's Well to help see to the various needs of the soldiers in camp.
The markings on this man's clothes identify him as an Uthgardt warrior of the Elk tribe.
This woman is obviously one of the many soldiers who have been recruited to the Lords' Alliance cause.
The markings on this woman's clothes identify her as an Uthgardt warrior of the Elk tribe.
This man is in charge of one of the Luskan catapults attacking Fort Ilkard.
This man is a captain in the Lords' Alliance army.
Lords' Alliance Captain
Lords' Alliance Soldier
This man bears markings identifying him as a sub-chief of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
This woman is one of the defenders of Fort Ilkard.
This halfling is one of the many commoners who has come to Beorunna's Well to aid the Lords' Alliance.
This man bears the tribal markings of the Uthgardt Elks.
This woman is obviously a cleric.
This wizard is one of many who fight alongside the soldiers of the Lords' Alliance.
Lords' Alliance Wizard
This man was wounded during the battle at Fort Ilkard.
This man wears the markings of an Elk tribe sub-chieftain.
This warrior of the Uthgardt Elk tribe shows signs of having been infected with the Wailing Death.
A nimbus of powerful magical energy surrounds this tiny fairy.
Old One Bodak Champion

Forged from solid iron, the crafting of these mighty juggernauts often requires the expertise and master craftwork of either dwarven blacksmiths or gnome artificers. This construct appears ancient, the product of a thousand years of vigilance, and nigh invulnerable.
Old One Guardian Golem
Though resembling the reptilian lizardmen, this creature possess a cruel intelligence not normally seen in the species.
This halfling is a brutalized slave.
Though resembling the reptilian humanoids known as lizardmen there is a cruel intelligence in the eyes of this creature not usually seen in the species.
This is one of the soldiers returning from the battles against the Elk tribe near Fort Ilkard to the south.
This man is one of the many soldiers defending Fort Ilkard.
This man is one of the defenders of Fort Ilkard.
This elven ranger is relaxed yet alert and obviously at ease in his current surroundings.
Vampire Champion
This orc bandit is as large and fearsome as his reputation would suggest.
This dwarf is armed and ready for battle.
This creature is composed of flame and fire.
It is obvious this elf is a practitioner of the arcane arts.
Though White Dragons are among the weakest of the wyrms of Faerun, this particular specimen's enormous size indicates it is of great age and formidable power.
(null)
Hill Giant Chieftain
Fire Giant Champion
Hill Giant Champion
Old One Champion
Ogre Archer
Bone Golem Champion
This young soldier seems to be more than a little into his cups already.
This middle-aged man has the look of an earnest and eager acolyte performing the will of his chosen god.
This is just one of the many off duty soldiers spending their time at the drinking house.
Though not wearing the traditional tribal dress of the Uthgardt, this young woman is obviously used to surviving in the wilds and forests of the northern frontier.
It is hard to decide what is more off-putting in this leecherous patron - the offensive leers he casts at every woman in the place, or the repulsive scabs and sores covering his skin.
Though shrunken and withered with age, the wise woman of the Uthgardt Black Lion tribe still commands respect.
The dwarven high priest of Tyr shows the strain of his recent relocation from Port Llast, yet he still manages to convey an air of confident authority.
The markings on this man's clothes identify him as an Uthgardt barbarian of the Black Lion tribe. Though obviously troubled he maintains an air of quiet dignity.
Though extremely rare in the Realms, this young woman's appearance leaves little doubt that she is a wild mage.
This man is a common merchant.
This woman is one of the settlers who has been conscripted into the army defending Fort Ilkard.
This man is one of the settlers who has been conscripted into the army defending Fort Ilkard.
This man is one of the many soldiers who has joined the Lords' Alliance cause.
This woman is a member of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
This child is a member of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
The markings on this woman's clothes identify her as a shaman of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
This man is a prisoner of the Elk tribe.
This woman's well tailored clothing hint at a life of wealth and luxury. Though a prisoner, she appears to have been well treated.
The markings on this man's clothes identify him as an Uthgardt barbarian of the Black Lion tribe.
The markings on this woman's clothes identify her as an Uthgardt barbarian of the Black Lion tribe.
The markings on this man's clothes identify him as an Uthgardt shaman of the Elk tribe.

As with most druids, there is something wild and untamed about this man - as if the fetters of civilization have no hold upon him. Yet in his eyes can be seen a gentle compassion toward all of nature's creatures.
This man wears the tribal dress of a chieftain of the Uthgardt Elk tribe.
Brunhilda's Diary

This appears to be the diary of Brunhilda Orelsdottr, a frost giant princess.
The entries are a hate-filled chronicle of the mistreatment and cruelty Brunhilda suffered at the hands of King Skrogg, the fire giant she was forced to marry nearly three months ago.
The final entry explains Brunhilda's ultimate fate:
Today in front of his court Skrogg vowed to consumate our marriage this very night. The coward will no doubt keep his entire retinue of guards in the room during our bedding for fear I may try to kill him, as I did the last time he dared to defile my bedchamber.
I will never let that pig touch me, though if I resist I know they will beat me again. I can endure the suffering and pain of this life no longer. Skrogg dares not kill me for fear of breaking the alliance with my mother, but tonight I shall take my own life and finally be free of this wretched existence.
This soft, gelatinous orb is a powerful magical component used in numerous spells.
The remains of these demonic, frog-like creatures contain many magical properties and are highly sought after by wizards for their experiments.

This parchment bears a powerful enchantment and a single command word of the type used to activate a magic portal. Mages and sorcerers often employ such scrolls as 'keys' to protect the entrances to their lairs or laboratories.
When read while standing within the area of an appropriate portal the scroll will instantly draw the reader through to the destination on the other side - wherever that may be.

This tome details the process of capturing a dragon's essence within a dragon sphere:
The ritual is most effective when used upon a newly hatched wyrm whose growth has been accelerated using spells and enchantments; a beast whose mind is still empty and pure. Only these have the vitality and energy of youth necessary to prolong the life of the mighty Klauth.
The creature to be absorbed must be lured or trapped within the center of the ritual room, and the dragon sphere must be placed upon the pedestal. The dragon's body will be instantly consumed even as its very life force is sucked into the sphere itself for Klauth to feed on at his leisure.
But a warning, lest you displease the master and suffer his terrible wrath: should a dead dragon's body be absorbed, the sphere must be destroyed immediately. If it is mistakenly presented to Klauth he may devour the essence of the dead wyrm, poisoning him and dealing his awesome might a crippling blow.

This sphere is roughly the size of an ogre's head and appears to be made of polished black stone, though it is far lighter than one would first expect.
The sphere radiates a powerful heat, and on closer inspection there appears to be a winged shape lying motionless beneath the smooth, dark surface - the captured essence of a dead dragon.

This sphere is roughly the size of an ogre's head and appears to be made of polished black stone, though it is far lighter than one would first expect.
The sphere radiates a powerful heat, and on closer inspection there appears to be a draconic shape slowly moving below the smooth, dark surface - the captured essence of a living dragon.

Writ of Authorization
This writ grants the bearer the authority to use any and all means necessary to bring the orc bandits Vaath and Guzud to justice.
A reward of 500 gold pieces will be paid upon delivery of the head of either bandit to my person.
Rolkid of the Mighty Lance

The florid, swooping, elongated hand in which this manuscript is written leaves little doubt as to its author. The wizard's mark on the inside cover further confirms that this is indeed one of the many tomes of magical item construction written by Hasuraman the Muddled.
"Though the secrets are known to me, the creation of the Amulet of Natural armor is not an endeavor I am likely to undertake, for reasons that at first glance should be obvious.
Fenberry, the complimentary component, presents no particular difficulty to the intrepid mage who wishes to acquire it in any substantial quantity.
However, the primary ingredient - the tongue of a slaad - poses challenges far beyond the capabilities of most. In the unlikely event one should encounter and defeat one of these demonic beings, the casting of Mage Armor is the only further requirement to obtaining the desired amulet.
Needless to say, anyone attempting the process beyond the confines of a carefully controlled environment such as a mage's laboratory would be doomed to encounter failure and disappointment."

The florid, swooping, elongated hand in which this manuscript is written leaves little doubt as to its author. The wizard's mark on the inside cover further confirms that this is indeed one of the many tomes of magical item construction written by Hasuraman the Muddled.
"The fashioning of the magical footwear known as Gargoyle Boots (or, as some insist on calling them, Boots of the Gargoyle) is an involved and difficult process not to be lightly undertaken.
Before beginning the procedure it is imperative that one perform said procedure within the confines of a proper mage's laboratory to avoid contaminations that would render the procedure ineffective.
As one might imagine, the primary ingredient is the skull of the creature that gives its name to the footwear. The skull must then be combined with a bodak's tooth and subjected to a stoneskin spell in order to complete the construction of said item."

The florid, swooping, elongated hand in which this manuscript is written leaves little doubt as to its author. The wizard's mark on the inside cover further confirms that this is indeed one of the many tomes of magical item construction written by Hasuraman the Muddled.
"The Staff of Power is an item of great power that can only be created by unleashing the power of similarly powerful items.
One such item is the bodak's tooth. When paired with a like twin, the bodak's tooth (or teeth, as would perhaps be more appropriate in this instance) must be enchanted with a feeblemind spell.
If these instructions are followed within the confines of a proper wizard's laboratory, the resulting item will be the all powerful Staff in question."

The florid, swooping, elongated hand in which this manuscript is written leaves little doubt as to its author. The wizard's mark on the inside cover further confirms that this is indeed one of the many tomes of magical item construction written by Hasuraman the Muddled.
"The Ring of Regeneration is an item eagerly sought after by both mage and warrior - not to mention priests and rogues. A perpetual fountain of healing magic constantly draining into one's own body is a boon to any man or woman, regardless of their profession.
Yet the creation of such an item is deceptively simple, if one merely possesses some fenberry and the eye of a rakshasa. (Of course acquiring said eye is another matter entirely - I have yet to meet the rakshasa that would part with one willingly.)
Once these ingredients are assembled the procedure can be completed using the equipment found in any standard mage's laboratory, supplemented with the casting of Melf's Acid Arrow on the combined ingredients."

The florid, swooping, elongated hand in which this manuscript is written leaves little doubt as to its author. The wizard's mark on the inside cover further confirms that this is indeed one of the many tomes of magical item construction written by Hasuraman the Muddled.
"Though an item of great use and application, the Crystal Robe is not without its peculiar failings. However, those willing to accept the drawbacks will be more than happy to reap the benefits of said item if they precisely follow my instructions, as follow:
Combine the belly of a fire beetle with one flawless quartz crystal in an appropriate magic container (the like of which can be found in any respectable wizard's laboratory).
Once the respective ingredients are in place, enchant them with an enervation spell to create the Crystal Robes."

This notebook identifies the bearer as an official representative of Tyr's justice in Rolgan's murder trial and explains the rules of court, including the right for defense council to question any of the participants involved before the trial begins.
To aid you in your task Neurik has included notes on the witnesses and jurors and where you might be able to locate them for questioning.
Witnesses: Rolgan - the accused. Currently under my protection in the Temple of Tyr. Zed - a Lords' Alliance soldier. Recently has been spending most of his time in the soldiers' barracks. Lodar - a Lords' Alliance soldier. Usually found in the drinking house when not on duty. Vanda - wife of the accused. Spends her time on the plateau by Beorunna's Well.
Jurors: The jurors have been selected to ensure a fair representation to all sides in the dispute.
Edegar - my assistant, a good and honest man. He is usually to be found here helping out in the temple. Averik - a Lords' Alliance soldier. When not in the company of a female he can be found in the drinking house. Jevon - a Lords' Alliance soldier. A reliable young man who spends most of his free time in the barracks. Dalcia - a female ranger. She spends her time living with the Uthgardt on the plateau near Beorunna's Well. Palla - a wise woman of the Uthgardt. She makes her home on the plateau near Beorunna's Well.

Roughly the size of an ogre's fist, this crystal sphere is far heavier than it would appear. Inside the globe can be seen an exquisitely detailed miniature realm, right down to the tiny figures of dwarves and dryads populating the landscape. From time to time the position of these figures seems to shift and change, as if they were somehow moving too slowly for the naked eye to see.
When flipped or turned drifting flakes of snow swirl and settle over the figures within the globe, covering the tiny world in a blanket of purest white. There is also a strong aura of magic surrounding the snow globe, and you sense that despite its fragile appearance it would be virtually impossible to destroy the glass casing.
Its size is impressive, with a unique quality and cut. This semi-precious stone has great value, particularly for those interested in the history of the Cheroux family.

Even in its dormant state, the magic contained within this artifact is undeniable. The surface of this heavy stone tablet tingles with raw energy and untapped potential, and the face and back are inscribed with the strange runes of a long forgotten alien tongue. The arcane symbols and unfamiliar glyphs pulsate and glow with a sinister inner light, bathing the entire stone in a warm reddish glow.
One can only imagine the unfathomable power that will be unleashed when the magic of the Word is fully awakened.

Blood stains the cover and many of the pages of this diary. Most of the entries are written in a firm, bold hand and describe the day-to-day activities of a settler family as they worked the fields and tilled the land. The final entry is written in a finer script:
"The Uthgardt fell upon us as we were working in the fields. There was no warning and we can find no reason for the sudden attack. Father stumbled when an arrow took him in the leg, but while the savages hacked away at his fallen form Mother and I escaped to the homestead and barred the doors.
"There is no escape for us now: the barbarians have the home surrounded. The soldiers at Fort Ilkard are too far away to arrive in time to save us, and I fear our neighbors are already dead. I can only pray that when the savages break through the door our deaths are merciful and quick."
Galia's baby
Galia holds a sleeping baby in her arms, wrapped in blankets.
Fairy Bottle
Through the dark glass of this bottle you see a small creature. It ignores you, concentrating instead on playing a variety of musical instruments that are scattered about the inside of the bottle.

This note appears to be instructions from a high priest to one of his underlings describing how to enter the central vault of the complex:
As a keeper of the sacred artifacts you must understand the secrets of our inner sanctum. Only the rituals of smoke, light and sound will unbind the door - there is no other way to enter its hallowed walls.
The enslaved fairy will guide you through the ritual of sound, for she is bound to the magic of the gongs.
To complete the ritual of smoke you must cast the blessed powders on the sacred brazier so that their combinations match the descending order of the stones set into brazier's base.
The ritual of light can only be completed using the stones drawn from the holy pool in the center of the pillars. Begin by placing any two of the single stones in the primary color pools. The secondary pools must then be filled with the twin gems that match the corresponding color that would be created by combining the hues of the stones in the primary pool.
You may keep this letter for a fortnight, and then you will be tested on what you have learned. Master the secrets of the rituals and the Queen will be pleased with you. Fail to learn them and you shall suffer a grisly fate.

The text of this brief letter is written in a plain and unremarkable script:
Dearest Mathilda:
I meant to send this note to offer you words of comfort, but even in a letter I cannot lie to you, my love. In the morning I am being sent out on patrol to verify reports of a strange ruin found far to the south of Fort Ilkard - further south than even the newly settled homesteads and farmlands. The last two patrols sent out were set upon by the Uthgardt and brutally slaughtered, and I fear I may never return from this mission.
Yet I am more troubled by the ever growing number of reports of defenseless settlers being butchered by the savages. I fear the homestead is no longer safe. You must take the children and flee Neverwinter as soon as you can.
I would come to escort you myself, but Commander Damas has a heart of stone. He has ordered anyone caught leaving their post without authorization to be hung as a deserter without trial. All I can do is send this note and pray it reaches you before the Uthgardt do.
Love, Willem
This is the decapitated head of an orc.

This note appears to have been left by Cyril, the mage who created this dungeon.
As I suspected, there are a number of natural pools in these underground chambers that can be easily converted into summoning cisterns. Once I have completed construction of my laboratory summoning a powerful elemental to do my bidding should simply require the addition of a Slaadi tongue to the pool, along with the casting of Melf's Acid Arrow.

This is the journal of Arwyl, leader of the snow globe dryads. The final entry is of particular interest:
The dwarves fell upon us yet again. Their savagery was terrifying, but at last I and my sisters managed to drive them off.
How many times was I slain in that battle, only to be reborn and slain yet again? Does it even matter anymore? War, death, rebirth - the cycle never ends.
In my dreams there are visions of a different world. I see dwarf and dryad working together, allied against a common and terrible foe in a bid to escape this pointless existence. And I remember the whisper of a powerful talisman, a tool to free both dryads and dwarves - the Amulet of Ages.
Is this a beautiful memory of a time long forgotten, or a promise of hope for the future? If we could only speak with the dwarves and make them understand...
But they are mad with bloodlust and attack us on sight. I fear this gruesome cycle will continue forever and this brutal existence will never end.

This is the journal of Hodd, leader of the snow globe dwarves. The final entry is of particular interest:
The dryads came at us again, using their foul magic. The fighting was bloody fierce, but at last we drove the tree huggers back.
How many times did I die in that battle only to be reborn and slain again? Does it even matter anymore? Fighting, death, rebirth, fighting - it never ends.
Sometimes in my dreams I see a different world. I see dwarf and dryad working together, allied against a common and terrible foe in a bid to escape this pointless existence. And I remember the fading echoes of a powerful talisman, a tool to free both them dryads and we dwarves - the Amulet of Ages.
Is it a memory of a time lost, or a hope for the future? If the dryads would only listen to reason then maybe...
But they are mad and attack us on sight. The fighting will never end and this pointless existence will continue forever.

The face of this amethyst has been inscribed with a symbol from a long forgotten alphabet. The enchantment on the stone allows even those unfamiliar with the archaic language to recognize the that the rune signifies 'Misery'.
The bottom of the stone contains a small groove, as if the gem had been intended for mounting on a stand or pedestal.

The face of this diamond has been inscribed with a symbol from a long forgotten alphabet. The enchantment on the stone allows even those unfamiliar with the archaic language to recognize the that the rune signifies 'Honor'.
The bottom of the stone contains a small grove, as if the gem had been intended for mounting on a stand or pedestal.

The face of this sapphire has been inscribed with a symbol from a long forgotten alphabet. The enchantment on the stone allows even those unfamiliar with the archaic language to recognize the that the rune signifies 'Pain'.
The bottom of the stone contains a small grove, as if the gem had been intended for mounting on a stand or pedestal.

The face of this emerald has been inscribed with a symbol from a long forgotten alphabet. The enchantment on the stone allow even those unfamiliar with the archaic language to recognize the that the rune signifies 'Duty'.
The bottom of the stone contains a small grove, as if the gem had been intended for mounting on a stand or pedestal.
Succubus Necklace
This necklace glitter darkly in your hands.
Succubus Ring
This ring glitters darkly in your hand.
Succubus Stone
A small stone glitters lightly in your hand; it has a strange beauty.

This note is written in the flawless script of a professional scribe. The bottom is marked with an official seal in the shape of a dragon's head:
A wise chieftain knows there is a time for war and there is a time for allegiance with and submission to a greater power. The time for petty warfare and tribal strife among the giants is over. King Skrogg has already bowed to my greatness, and has reaped the rewards for his people. Now I demand the same from you.
As proof of your allegiance I require tribute in the form of undamaged, living eggs seized from the lairs of the dragons throughout these mountains. Should you agree to my terms I will reward you with a thousand pieces of gold for each dragon egg delivered to my lair. Should you refuse I will destroy you and all your tribe.
You may give your answer to my envoy, who will convey your message back to me with the utmost urgency.
Klauth the Terrible, Overlord of the Mountains and Ruler of the North

This letter is penned in a crude, almost child-like hand and there are numerous spelling errors in the text. Based on the poorly rendered seal at the bottom of the page it would be safe to assume this was some type of official correspondence from the hill giant chieftain:
You big tuff master. Me no want be squiched. Me tribe give tribeaut and eggs and stuff. We want lots gold. Them fire giants say you big good master. We want be frend with you. Klauth be boss and we be servents.
Green Dragon Egg
Gold Dragon Egg

M3Q3D_DOORSHUT
This magical door is locked with three powerful locks, each of which can be disarmed only by completing one of the puzzles within this dungeon.
LizardMen
Merchant Ambush
Bats
A simple pedestal, its basin filled with shimmering water.

Fireball Waypoint
Fire Elemental Way Point
Hell Hound Waypoint
Rolgan's Trial

Neurik, the cleric at Tyr's temple, needs someone to defend Rolgan, an Uthgardt tribesman accused of murder.
The details of the case are included in a trial notebook, including the names of witnesses and jurors that must be spoken to in preparing an adequate case for the defense.
When you are ready to start the trial, go speak to Neurik at the Temple of Tyr.
[Trial will begin as soon as you enter the trial room]

Rolgan's trial is in progress. By law, should anything interrupt the procedings the young man will instantly be found guilty and executed.
The justice of Tyr can be both swift and harsh.

Rolgan's trial is over. The unfortunate young man's decapitated head staring from atop the pike outside the Temple door is stark evidence of the poor case presented by his defense council.
No doubt this outcome will increase tensions between the Uthgardt and the Lords' Alliance.

Rolgan's trial is over. The young man owes his life to the skillful case presented by his defense council.
The Uthgardt and Neurik are pleased that Tyr's justice has been served, though there are lingering doubts among the Lords' Alliance as to whether a guilty man has gone free.

Rolgan's trial is over. The young man undoubtably owes his life to the brilliant case presented by defense council.
Neurik is elated with the unanimous verdict, for such an overwhelming verdict forces even the soldiers of the Lords' Alliance to admit (grudgingly) that justice has been served.

The death of one of the participants has indefinitely postponed Rolgan's trial. It may be months before Neurik resumes the proceedings in this matter. Anyone investigating the trial would be better served searching for the Words of Power.
Save the Supply Lines

Rolkid of the Mighty Lance, supply master for Beorunna's Well, wants to send a message to the raiders attacking the Lords' Alliance supply lines.
He has offered a substantial bounty to anyone who delivers him the heads of the infamous orc bandits Vaath and Guzud.
The head of Vaath has been delivered to Rolkid and promptly placed upon a stake outside the barracks. The reward for Guzud's head is still up for grabs.
The head of Guzud has been delivered to Rolkid and promptly placed upon a stake outside the barracks. The reward for Vaath's head is still up for grabs.

The heads of the orcish bandits Vaath and Guzud adorn the twin stakes flanking the entrance to the soldiers barracks in Beournna's Well. The infamous raiders will trouble the supply lines of the Lords' Alliance no more.
Rolkid now seeks the head of Obould Many-Arrows, a powerful orcish chieftain, to complete his collection. Needless to say, he has put up a substantial reward.
The head of Obould Many-Arrows has been delivered to Rolkid of the Mighty lance, and the threat to the Lords' Alliance supply lines has been well and truly vanquished.
The Snow Globe

Lillian Cambridge is looking for a brave adventurer to recover a valuable snow globe stolen from her by a wizard named Nax.
In exchange she has offered to reveal the location of one of the Words of Power.
She believes Nax is exploring an ancient mage's laboratory somewhere in the Coldwood - a lab accessible only by using a very special teleportation scroll.

The snow globe has been returned to Lillian Cambridge. As promised she has revealed the location of one of the Words of Power: a miniature world inside the snow globe itself!
The snow globe has been magically transported to its pedestal in Lillian's room, located upstairs in the drinking house of Beorunna's Well.
As long as the wine keeps flowing in the tavern she doesn't seem to care who goes into her room to access the miniature world inside the snow globe.
The Word of Power has been recovered from inside the snow globe, destroying the miniature world within and freeing the dwarves and dryads from their their endless torment.

The world inside the snow globe is populated by dryads and dwarves locked in a neverending war. Those slain in battle are instantly reborn to continue the fight.
But there are hints that once the dwarves and dryads served together as slaves under an evil master.
Maybe this master knows something about the Word of Power hidden in this world.

The snow globe is obviously a powerful artifact. Lillian Cambridge - the archeologist Aarin Gend mentioned could be found in the drinking house at Beorunna's Well - might be able to provide more information about it.
Words of Power

Words of Power
The Words of Power must be found before Maugrim and his cult locate them and turn the ancient artifacts against Neverwinter. Though lost for centuries, reports indicate that three of the Words can be found in the lands near Beorunna's Well.
As the Words are located, they should be brought back to Aarin Gend at Beorunna's Well so they can be delivered to the safety of Castle Never.

Words of Power
The first of the three Words of Power has been found and safely delivered to Aarin Gend, but the enemy is not beaten yet.
Maugrim and his cult continue to search the lands around Beorunna's Well - a sure sign there are other Words yet to be found.
As the Words are located, they should be brought back to Aarin Gend at Beorunna's Well so they can be delivered to the safety of Castle Never.

Words of Power
The second of the three Words of Power has been found and safely delivered to Aarin Gend, but the enemy is not beaten yet.
Maugrim and his cult continue to search the lands around Beorunna's Well - a sure sign there are other Words yet to be found.
As the Words are located, they should be brought back to Aarin Gend at Beorunna's Well so they can be delivered to the safety of Castle Never.

Words of Power
The third Word of Power has been found but there is no time for celebration.
Aribeth and the Luskan army have breached the walls of Neverwinter.
Aarin Gend has made all the preparations for a quick return to Neverwinter. If Aribeth and the Luskan army are not stopped the city will surely fall.
The Siege of Fort Ilkard

With the Uthgardt catapults destroyed, Captain Damas is determined to end the siege of Fort Ilkard.
He has promised a reward to anyone who can bring him the head of Arness, the Elk tribe sub-chieftain in charge of the forces laying siege to Fort Ilkard.

With the siege on Fort Ilkard ended, Captain Damas seeks to destroy the Elk tribe once and for all.
He has offered a reward to anyone who can get to their enclave in the west and bring back the head of their chieftain, Zokan Thunderer.
With the head of Zokan Thunderer delivered into his lap, Commander Damas and Fort Ilkard have little to fear from the Elk tribe any longer.
Commander Damas has promised to reward anyone who can destroy the catapults attacking Fort Ilkard.

Commander Damas has admitted he infected the Elk tribe with the Wailing Death. However, he feels no remorse for his actions.
A difficult moral decision lies ahead - deliver the plague cure to Zokan Thunderer and save the Elk tribe, or bring the chieftain's severed head to Commander Damas and collect the offered reward.
The Elk tribe have been cured of the plague they contracted from the infected blankets - a gift from Commander Damas of Fort Ilkard.
Bring Bret's Family to Fort Ilkard
Bret, a soldier at Fort Ilkard, fears for the safety of his young wife and newborn child. He has promised a reward if they are escorted from his homestead in the west to the safety of Fort Ilkard.
Bret's wife has agreed to follow you to the safety of Fort Ilkard.
Bret and his family have been reunited within the safety of Fort Ilkard's walls.
Bret's wife and daughter have been slain, though it might be best if the young man does not learn of their fate until after his service at Fort Ilkard is over.
After reaching the safety of the road leading to Fort Ilkard, Bret's wife has rushed on ahead to be reunited with her husband.
Deliver Eckel's Note

Eckel the gnome needs a note delivered to his wife in the homesteads to the west of Fort Ilkard.
If the list of prospective buyers for his turnip crop is not delivered, Eckel is afraid he might lose his farm.
Eckel's list of prospective buyers for his turnip crop has been delivered to his wife, saving the farm from financial ruin.
Eckel's wife has been slain, though it would be best if he did not learn of her fate until after his service at Fort Ilkard has ended.
NON JOURNAL, Small Rewards
Investigate the Elk Tribe

Yusam is looking for someone to investigate the Uthgardt Elk tribe. The druid is convinced there must be some reason they have turned away from the Lords' Alliance and joined with the Luskan army.
Yusam believes the Elk tribe and their leader, Zokan Thunderer, are in a keep to the west of Fort Ilkard.
Zokan Thunderer, leader of the Elk tribe, is no more. Upon hearing the news Yusam, Druid of the North, was saddened, though he understood the necessity of the Elk tribe's destruction.

The Elk tribe have been cured of the plague given to them by Commander Damas of Fort Ilkard, and will no longer aid the Luskan army in its battle against Neverwinter.
Yusam the Druid was pleased to learn the children of the Elk will once more welcome his counsel.
Free Nax

A wizard named Nax has become trapped behind an impassable wall of fire while exploring a long deserted mage's laboratory.
He has offered a reward of a magical snow globe if he is released from his prison.

Nax has been freed, but he did not deliver the snow globe as promised.
Nax did say the key to finding the snow globe was a series of magical gongs struck in the proper order, which seems to have something to do with the creatures summoned during an ancient battle between the mage Cyril Lyricus and the Mountain Hag Nebacha.
The animals summoned were a cat, dog, bear and dragon.
Nax has been freed from his prison.
Recover the Star Sapphire

Husher Clay of the adventuring gear shop is looking for someone to bring him the Star Sapphire.
The gem was buried with the mage Layenne Cheroux, whose trap-infested tomb is believed to be hidden somewhere in the Coldwood.
The Star Sapphire has been delivered to Husher Clay.
Working for Akulatraxas

The green dragon Akulatraxas has been under attack from hill giants seeking to steal her eggs.
She has offered treasure from her hoard to anyone who brings her the hill giant chieftain's head, telling them to seek out the hill giants' lair west of her cave.
The head of the hill giant chieftain has been given to the green dragon Akulatraxas, ending the threat to her eggs.
The green dragon Akulatraxas has been slain.
Gorgotha the Gold Dragon

The servants of Klauth, an ancient red wyrm, have been attacking the lair of the gold dragon Gorgotha.
In exchange for Klauth's head Gorgotha has offered a share of her treasure hoard.
The head of the wyrm Klauth has been delivered to the dragon Gorgotha, assuring her of the continued survival of her eggs.
The gold dragon Gorgotha has been slain.
Klauth the Ancient Red Wyrm

Klauth, the great red wyrm of the North, has admitted to having one of the Words of Power in his possession.
He has offered to exchange the Word of Power for the eggs of another dragon.
Klauth has traded the Word of Power he possessed for the dragon's eggs he needs to perform his dark rituals.
Klauth, ancient red wyrm of the North, is dead.
Plant the Ultarg Tree Seeds

A wild mage named Sapphira needs someone to travel back in time 10,000 years to plant the seeds of the rare Ultarg Tree so that she can harvest the fruit here in the present. The seeds must be planted beneath the red warding rune in the garden of the ancient past.
Sapphira explained that using the power of a time crystal on one of the sundials in the Creator Race ruins will draw a person back into the past, and using it in the same manner in the past will bring them back to the present.
She also mentioned that one of the Words of Power might be found in the vault at the center of the Creator Race ruins.

The seeds have been planted in the past and a magnificent Ultarg Tree has sprouted up in the present day.
Now Sapphira will be able to harvest the fruit she has so eagerly been waiting for.
Sapphira, the time travelling wild mage, is dead. With her passing it is unlikely anyone else in Faerun will care whether the Ultarg Tree ever bears fruit.
As befitting a represntative of the Many Starred Cloak, there is both sage wisdom and an element of dark and dangerous knowledge in Eltoora's gaze.

This is the journal of Arwyl, leader of the snow globe dryads. The final entry is of particular interest:
The dwarves fell upon us yet again. There savagery was terrifying, but at last I and my sisters managed to drive them off.
How many times was I slain in that battle, only to be reborn and slain yet again? Does it even matter anymore? War, death, rebirth - the cycle never ends.
In my dreams there are visions of a different world. I see dwarf and dryad working together, allied against a common and terrible foe in a bid to escape this pointless existence.
Is this a beautiful memory of a time long forgotten, or a promise of hope for the future? If we could only speak with the dwarves and make them understand...
But they are mad with bloodlust and attack us on sight. I fear this gruesome cycle will continue forever and this brutal existence will never end.

This is the journal of Hodd, leader of the snow globe dwarves. The final entry is of particular interest:
The dryads came at us again, using their foul magic. The fighting was bloody fierce, but at last we drove the tree huggers back.
How many times did I die in that battle only to be reborn and slain again? Does it even matter anymore? Fighting, death, rebirth, fighting - it never ends.
Sometimes in my dreams I see a different world. I see dwarf and dryad working together, allied against a common and terrible foe in a bid to escape this pointless existence.
Is it a memory of a time lost, or a hope for the future? If the dryads would only listen to reason then maybe...
But they are mad and attack us on sight. The fighting will never end and this pointless existence will continue forever.

It is obvious powerful magical enchantments have been placed on this pedestal, likely to protect something of great value. The protections on the central pedestal seem to be linked to the four surrounding pedestals in this room.
(null)
The ceremonial markings on this Uthgardt barbarian are those of a shaman of the Golden Eagle tribe.
There is an evil glint of desperate cunning in the eye of this emerald scaled wyrm.
By the look of this brass dragon's scarred corpse it had recently laid a clutch of eggs; the fragments of shell still linger in the dragon's dead claws.
From the great claw wounds on this corpse it is obvious this fire giant was slain during a fearsome battle with a dragon.
This elf is a prisoner of the Fire Giants.
This woman is a prisoner of the Fire Giants.
East to Fire Giant Domain
The aura of true majesty one would expect in an adult blue dragon is undercut by the vapid, mindless expression on this beast's face.
Intruder! Destroy! Destroy!
Me got Word of Power number four right here!
I have the fourth Word of Power right here!
You move or me make sure you be one in jail!
Out of my way or you'll be the one rotting in a cell!
You're the one Nasher sent to check on the prisoner, ain't you? Go on in.
Now don't be gettin' all upset now! I'm just doin' me job! You can't just waltz in here and... oh, wait a minute!
You're that <man/woman> Nasher sent to check on the prisoner, ain't you? Go on in.
The soldiers won't be able to hold the City Core much longer. Soon the enemy will break through and slaughter us all!
You're the hero who saved us from the Wailing Death! Have you come here to save the city one last time, or are you trapped here like the rest of us?
I used to admire Aribeth, but her betrayal has doomed us all! I hope she burns in the Nine Hells for what she's done!
Have you heard the stories about what the Luskan soldiers do to the civilians they capture? Maybe it would have been better if I had died from the plague!
Look at all the wounded in this place. I heard most of them fell trying to defend the southern section of the city.
I know you - you saved us from the Wailing Death! You gonna save us all from these Luskan invaders, too?
I used to look down on everyone who worked here, but maybe I was wrong. Ophala and her girls seem to bring some comfort to the dying soldiers, at least.
I never thought I'd come to a place like this, but when the Luskanites burned my home I had nowhere else to go. And that young Tanith who works here sure is handsome...
The soldiers here are saying the Luskan army doesn't take prisoners. They'll kill us all if they breach the south gates!
Hey, I know you! You're that hero who saved us from the Wailing Death! Have you come to save the city, or are you trapped here with the rest of us?
I pray to Tyr every day for the sake of the soldiers who fall at the South Gate.
I barely escaped with my life when the Luskan army burned my home. I came here because I had nowhere else to go.
Impudent slave, you will die!
The soldiers won't be able to hold the city core much longer. Soon the enemy will break through and slaughter us all!
You're the hero who saved us from the Wailing Death! Have you come here to save the city one last time, or are you trapped here like the rest of us?
The soldiers who survived the fighting in the southern section of the city are saying the Luskanites don't take prisoners! They'll kill us all when they get here!
First the Wailing Death and now the Luskan invaders... it seems like Neverwinter is cursed!
Look at all the wounded in this place. Most of them fell trying to defend the southern districts of the city, or so I heard.
How come a hero like you is here at the Moonstone Mask instead of fighting the Luskan army in the southern section of the city?
Ophala and her girls are angels, I tell you. Beautiful angels who look after all the sick and dying in this place.
I figure the city is doomed, so I want to spend my last days here in the Moonstone Mask... I've got a lot of happy memories from this place.
The soldiers here are saying the Luskan army doesn't take prisoners. They'll kill us all if they breach the south gates!
Hey, I know you! You're that hero who saved us from the Wailing Death! Have you come to save the city, or are you trapped here with the rest of us?
I thought this temple would be a good place to come when the Luskans burned my house, but maybe I should have gone to the Moonstone Mask. The girls there were always so kind to me.
This place is already too crowded, but Oleff won't turn anyone away. And now that the southern section of the city has fallen the refugees will just keep coming.
I wish I could help you, but I have to get back to the patients.
Please step back; the patients need their sleep.
Talk to the priest; I'm busy right now, I'm sorry.
This man is bleeding; I can't help you, I'm sorry.
Half the soldiers in my platoon fell when the enemy breached the walls. Damn that traitor Aribeth - I hope when this is all over she pays for what she's done!
The entire south section of the city is overrun by the enemy. The city core is the last safe place in Neverwinter... for now.
Thank the gods you're here! Maybe you can save us from these Luskan invaders!
We're trying to keep civilians off the streets - but you can go wherever you want.
Those Luskan dogs are merciless. I hear they don't even take prisoners - if you try to surrender they just cut you down where you stand!
We're trapped here in the city core - there's no escape for any of us. Soon the enemy will break through the south gates and slaughter us all.
You may have saved us from the Wailing Death, but I don't think even you can defeat a whole army. This city is doomed.
We lost a lot of good men and women trying to hold the area south of the city core, but the invaders overwhelmed us. There were just too many of them!
Version 8.7
Those Luskan dogs are merciless. I hear they don't even take prisoners - if you try to surrender they just cut you down where you stand!
You're the hero who saved us from the Wailing Death! Have you come here to save the city one last time, or are you trapped here like the rest of us?
My wounds are bad, but at least I'm still alive. That's more than most of my company can say.
Between the catapults and war golems we didn't stand a chance against the invaders. They took the south section of the city.
I am too busy to talk right now.

With the latest setbacks in the war to save the city, all hope seems to have drained from Aarin Gend's features. Yet blazing in his eyes is a grim determination to fight for Neverwinter to his dying breath.
The leader of the Word Slaves holds the wisdom of ten thousand years in her eyes - along with a terrible understanding of what will happen should Morag be reborn into the Realms.
The suffering of his city weighs heavily upon Lord Nasher, though his features are set in a grim determination to see this latest crisis through to the end... whatever the outcome.
Though more attuned to nature, it is obvious the suffering of the city weighs heavily upon the druid.
Luce shows no signs of moving from the small corner she is in.
The matron of the Moonstone Mask looks as though she has hardly slept in days.
The suffering of the wounded soldiers has been greatly alleved by the cheerful bedside manner of this attractive gnome.
The bloodstains on this handsome young man's clothes attest to his willingness to tend to the wounded with no regard for his appearance.
This man is one of the many soldiers still fighting to save Neverwinter.
This is one of the many brave Neverwinter soldiers who still stands against the Luskan horde.
There is a grace and fluidity in the movements of this elf that hint at her skill with a blade.
The grim expression on this half-orc storekeeper's face reveals that he knows all too well what will happen to the citizens of Neverwinter should the City Core fall.
Captain Aethelred
This man stands rigidly at attention, intent on fulfilling his guard duties until the gates to the City Core have fallen.
This little girl seems strangely out of place in this war ravaged city.
This old man is obviously blind.
The body of the man who unleashed the plague on Neverwinter has been ravaged by death and decay as the evil power he serves consumes him from within.
An insatiable lust for knowledge gives a twinkle to the eye of this aged archeologist, though beneath the gleam there is a hint of a dark and sinister shadow.
This young woman's eyes are quick and intelligent, though something is obviously troubling her.
The haughty arrogance with which this young gnome carries himself is obviously a false front hiding deep seated insecurities about his own worth.
Gedry has been your best friend and closest ally in your efforts to free the slaves from the tyranny of the Old Ones.
The Keeper of the Ravens has been a valuable ally to the slave underground, yet you cannot help but feel something is amiss when you look at him.
There is a cruel arrogance in this reptilian humanoid's bearing.
Though only a projection there is no denying the imperious cruelty of Morag, Queen of the Old Ones.
The Queen of the Old Ones embodies all the royal majesty, ancient power and evil cruelty of the Creator Race.
From his strictly rigid posture it is obvious this gnome takes his guard duties very seriously.
The representative of the guild of the Many Starred Cloak is doing her best to put on a brave front in the face of impending doom for the city she loves.
The cleric of Tyr does his best to keep his spirits up for the sake of those seeking refuge in his church.
This is one of the Luskan war wizards intent on destroying the city.
The evil shadow has lifted from Aribeth's face, though there is still sadness upon her features. However, for the first time since Fenthick's death there is a peaceful acceptance in her eyes.
Though dressed in clothing from a strange and unfamiliar land, the physical resemblance between this elven paladin and Aribeth is uncanny.
These elite guards are chosen from among the largest and strongest of the Creator Race.
This cleric of the Old Ones calls upon ancient evil Gods for its powers.
This cleric is in deep meditation, completely focused on maintaining one of the spells that shields Morag from harm.
The evokers of the Old Ones know dark secrets of the arcane.

This soldier is one of the Luskan invaders.

Adventurer's Diary

This appears to be a set of notes, written carefully:
The puzzle of light and dark haunts me; I know there's a key in here somewhere. But where? It is a strange labyrinth, and half the time I end up back where I began.
I do know that carrying the torch is part of the light. But the light only goes so far; eventually, you have to enter the dark.

A Leader of the Slave Resistance

Part of you wants to flee this place, but you know to do so would be certain death, for that is the punishment of a slave caught in the streets breaking curfew.
Perhaps you are just nervous, as the Creator Race are growing ever closer to discovering this place - the headquarters of the slave reistance. Yet you know there is something more to these strange feelings.
Perhaps the notebook you always keep in your inventory can help make things more clear.
You have escaped the Past Life Trap by proving the world around you was not real, thereby dispelling the illusion.
The Final Battle

Led by Aribeth and Maugrim the Luskan forces have all but overrun Neverwinter. Even slaying the leaders might not be enough to turn the tide of battle at this point.
Aarin Gend feels Haedraline, the mysterious lizard creature now languishing in the dungeons of Castle Never, might know a way to save the city.
Only she can reveal the secrets of the Words of Power and the recently discovered Source Stone, although there is hope that Master Ford - presently studying the Source Stone in the caverns beneath the dungeon of Castle Never - might have some information to share as well.

Haedraline has revealed that the fourth and final Word of Power is in the hands of Maugrim. The mad prophet plans to use its power to awaken Morag and the Old Ones from their hibernation within the Source Stone so they may once again enslave all of Faerun.
The only way to stop the Old Ones' return is to find the fourth Word of Power and bring it to Haedraline before Queen Morag grows strong enough to awaken her people.
There is word that Maugrim is hiding out in the war zone south of the city, protected by the Luskan forces.

The fourth Word of Power has been recovered and brought to Haedraline... but perhaps it is already too late.
Morag's strength has grown too powerful, her return is inevitable. The only way to stop her now is to use the Words of Power to enter the Source Stone beneath Castle Never's dungeons and destroy Morag once and for all.

Somewhere in the extra-planar world within the Source Stone Morag prepares the rituals that will release her people from their 10,000 year imprisonment.
If she is not stopped before the ritual is complete the brutal Creator Race will once again conquer all of Faerun, and the world as it now exists will be utterly destroyed.

Morag has been destroyed. And with the Queen's death, the threat of the Old Ones return is no more.
Without Morag's power to sustain them spirit of the Luskan horde is broken and the invaders are quickly routed by the newly inspired Neverwinter forces.
Aribeth's Fate

Aribeth's tragic tale of grief and betrayal is finally over. She has been united with Fenthick in death.
Perhaps now she has found the peace she could not in life.

Aribeth has abandoned Morag's cause and surrendered herself to Lord Nasher to accept judgment for her betrayal of the city.
Once an instrument of vengeance and destruction, Aribeth seems to have found peace at last.
She is now willing to accept whatever fate awaits her: execution, banishment... or perhaps even forgiveness and redemption.
Rescue Leesa

Luce, one of the working girls at the Moonstone Mask, is desperate for someone to find her little sister, Leesa.
The girl was last seen in the Luskan controlled area of the city.
Leesa has agreed to return to the Moonstone Mask, where she can be reunited with her sister Luce.
Leesa and Luce have been reunited in the relative safety of the Moonstone Mask.
Leesa, the young sister of Luce at the Moonstone Mask, is dead - another casualty of this terrible war.
Neverwinter Under Siege

Between the catapult fire and the unstoppable war golems of the enemy, the soldiers of Neverwinter can do little to stop the Luskan advance.
If the catapults could be destroyed and the wizards controlling the war golems stopped then at least the brave defenders might have a faint hope of turning back the invaders.

The war golems are defeated, but the catapults continue to rain death down upon the heads of the Neverwinter soldiers.
Perhaps if the catapults could be destroyed the defenders might have some slim hope of saving the city.

The catapults have been destroyed, but the unstoppable war golems continue to wreak havoc in the streets.
Perhaps if the wizards controlling the war golems could be found and slain the defenders might have some slim hope of saving the city.
With the catapults destroyed and the war golems vanquished the defenders of Neverwinter have been given some small hope of resisting the Luskan invasion.
This young woman's face is haggard and drawn from her constant tending to the needs of the wounded.
Goodbye.
Tell me 'bout how stores work.
Tell me 'bout how inventory work.
Me got questions me want ask.
Me want see what you sell.
Can you explain how stores work?
Can you explain how my inventory works?
I want to ask you some questions.
You know stuff 'bout a cure?
You know stuff 'bout plague?
You talk 'bout you self, Olgerd.
Have you heard anything about a cure?
Lady Aribeth?
Me want meet Lady Aribeth.
I'd like to meet the Lady Aribeth.
What can you tell me about the plague?
Tell me about yourself, Olgerd.
I want to see what you have for sale.
Okay.
Welcome back, <FirstName>. So what can old Olgerd do for you? You want to take a peek inside my shop, or is there something else?
Of course you do, my simple minded friend.
As long as you're here at the Academy, feel free to come back and speak to me anytime you need to purchase more equipment.
I'll do my best to answer your questions, though I don't know much. I haven't left the Academy since the plague hit.

All I know about that is the rumors going around the barracks. They say Khelben "Blackstaff" Arunsun, the famous mage, has discovered that a cure can be made using reagents gathered from rare and exotic beasts.
Supposedly these creatures have been brought from Waterdeep to the Academy for safekeeping. I don't know if that's true, but why else would Lady Aribeth be here?
Surely you've heard of Lady Aribeth de Tylmarande, the Elven paladin of Tyr. Nasher Alagondar, Lord of Neverwinter, has appointed her to find a cure for the Wailing Death.

Officially she's here at the Academy to inspire and motivate the new recurits with the blessings of Tyr. But the whispered word is she's also here to keep an eye on those Waterdhavian creatures they hope to turn into a cure.
So would I. Her beauty is only surpassed by her ability and her devotion to Tyr, or so they say. She's young, but she's already a legend here in Neverwinter.
Maybe when my shift is done I'll get a chance to go see her. She's giving out blessings in the south assembly chamber. It's just through these doors and down the hall.
Is there anything else you want to ask me?
A foul business, the Wailing Death. The bodies just keep piling up in the street and healers, clerics and priests are powerless to help. That's mighty suspicious if you ask me.

This ain't no natural plague, mark my words! The instructors here at the Academy don't like to talk about it, but I think somebody or something brought the Wailing Death upon us for some fell purpose.

I guess the authorities don't want to speculate about that, though. There's enough panic in the streets as it is. Or maybe they're just focusing on the cure before they start worrying about what was behind all this.
Huh? It's rare anyone asks about me. Not much to tell, really. As a young man I came to the Academy so I could join the Neverwinter militia and serve my city.
I served nearly a hundred and forty years, until my hair grew gray, my eyes grew dim and my back bent with age. But I had no family, no wife or kids, and I didn't want to retire.

So they were kind enough to give me this job here at the Academy, helping out you new recruits by giving you quality equipment at a reasonable price. So that's it, my life in a nutshell. Anything else I can do for you?
Certainly. As long as you're here at the Academy my store is at your service.

All stores are accessed through dialog. Just talk to a shopkeeper and tell him you want to see what he has for sale. This will bring up the store inventory menu on the left of the screen, and your own inventory will appear on the right.
Okay. To access your inventory, simply press "i" on your keyboard or left-click on the inventory icon below your portrait in the upper right corner of the screen. We've highlighted the icon for you.
No. Me need you say that last stuff again.
No. Can you repeat that last part about the journal again?
Yes.
Go ahead and close your journal now. You can do this by hitting the "J" on your keyboard or by clicking the journal icon under your character portrait.
Now I'm going to update your journal. Open your journal again. You'll see the "Speaking to Berna" entry has been moved. It's now in the Completed Quests section of your journal.

Notice that on the top of the journal are tabs for your quests, your completed quests and a section where you can make your own notes. As I already mentioned, the "Speaking To Berna" entry is now under the completed quests tab.
Click on the entry. Notice how it's changed to tell you the quest is now over. That's about it for the journal. Do you want me to go on to the map tutorial now?
I'm Ferdinand, the Academy's resident Keeper of Exotic Creatures. I'm in charge of the Menagerie here. We've met before... but I guess you've been busy with your training so you must have forgotten.

This Academy was founded with the purpose of training adventurers, so it only makes sense that we would collect strange and exotic monsters - the kind adventurers might encounter during their explorations.
Well, looks like you're ready to go and complete your training. Just head on through the door and you'll find Olgerd waiting for you.
Well, looks like you're ready to go and complete your training. Just head on through the door and you'll find Olgerd waiting for you.

You can right-click on any object or creature in the game, including yourself. This is VERY important to remember, as right-clicking will bring up a menu that lets you access most of your abilities and actions.
Try right-clicking on me to bring up the menu, then select the attack icon on the right of the menu to punch me. The attack icon is at the 3 o'clock position on the menu.

You can right-click on any object or creature in the game, including yourself. This is VERY important to remember, as right-clicking will bring up a menu that lets you access most of your abilities and actions.
Try right-clicking on me to bring up the menu, then select the attack icon on the right of the menu to punch me. The attack icon is at the 3 o'clock position on the menu.
Well, looks like you're ready to go and complete your training. Just head on through the door and you'll find Olgerd waiting for you.
Goodbye.
Some got what it takes. Some don't got it.
Some people have what it takes, some don't.
You just got to stick with it.
You just have to stick with it, Pavel.
I need to speak to you.
I owe you my life, <FirstName>. Without you, I wouldn't have made it out of here. I... I could have died, just like my brother.
You've got what it takes to be a great hero, <FirstName>, maybe even a legend. But this life isn't for me. I know that now.
Thank you once more for saving me. I know you'll be a great hero someday. But I don't want to risk my neck for fame and fortune.
I'm no hero. I just want a nice, quiet life. I doubt our paths will cross again anytime soon. Goodbye, <FirstName>, and good luck.
Your words are truer than you know. Heroes are born, not made.
All I could think about in there was how afraid I was of dying. I wanted to curl up in a corner and just close my eyes to everything. Those aren't the thoughts of a hero.
I'm no hero. I just want a nice, quiet life. I doubt our paths will cross again anytime soon. Goodbye and good luck.
Ahhhh! Monster! Kill it. I'm too old for this sort of thing.
This goblin looks much tougher than those you have faced thus far.
Speaking To Berna
Berna is explaining the journal system to me.
After speaking to Berna I now understand how to use the journal.
